channel.title: Comments on: If you think uninstalling SQL Server is a pain, have fun with Oracle
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: itoctopus
item.dc:creator: itoctopus
item.content:encoded:
No matter how hard it is to uninstall Oracle, it is still much easier than installing it.

It seems that Oracle intentionally makes it really hard to install/uninstall its products – perhaps because it wants those certified Oracle engineers to get contracts.

item.title: By: Martin Wei
item.dc:creator: Martin Wei
item.description: On Linux I just needed to stop the oracle service, delete the init-skript and the ORACLE_HOME folder und was done...
item.content:encoded: On Linux I just needed to stop the oracle service, delete the init-skript and the ORACLE_HOME folder und was done…

item.title: By: terry
item.dc:creator: terry
item.description: Honestly, I don't know what's difficult at all about uninstalling Sql Server. I install and uninstall it numerous times for users at work and it is as zero friction as you can get. Just hit next and then next. Really simple. <br /> Looking at the Oracle uninstall process though looks to be truly horrific and filled with steps that should be automated without the user having to touch it very much at all.
item.content:encoded:
Honestly, I don’t know what’s difficult at all about uninstalling Sql Server. I install and uninstall it numerous times for users at work and it is as zero friction as you can get. Just hit next and then next. Really simple.
Looking at the Oracle uninstall process though looks to be truly horrific and filled with steps that should be automated without the user having to touch it very much at all.

item.title: By: Aleksey
item.dc:creator: Aleksey
item.content:encoded:
There is nothing easier than removing Oracle from Windows box. Hmm… Actually, I’m wrong. It’s even easier on Unix.

Anyway, if a OUI doesn’t work the way you expected then stop all remaining Oracle services, remove directory where Oracle was installed. Then remove registry keys under HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINESOFTWAREORACLE. If you have any Oracle services left then remove them under HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINESYSTEMCurrentControlSetServices. Restart your computer. Done.

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.description: I didn't get the same kind of issues with SQL Server, I uninstalled Visual Studio 2012 and SQL Server 2012 without a problem in order to install SQl Server 2014 CTP1
item.content:encoded: I didn’t get the same kind of issues with SQL Server, I uninstalled Visual Studio 2012 and SQL Server 2012 without a problem in order to install SQl Server 2014 CTP1

item.title: By: Jamie Thomson
item.dc:creator: Jamie Thomson
item.content:encoded:
I got a reply from Tim Ford ” Its easier to just rebuild the server.”

I’d argue the same holds true for SQL Server too!!!
